node.id: Mary Ingram, Amy, and Louisa Eshton required permission from Miss Ingram to visit the library because she was the one who had initially gone to see the fortune-teller and they were afraid to go alone. The nervous reactions inside the library could be attributed to the fact that the fortune-teller seemed to know a lot of personal details about them, such as things they had said and done when they were children, books and ornaments in their boudoirs, keepsakes presented by different relations, and even their thoughts and desires. This accurate and specific information made them believe that the fortune-teller was not an ordinary person but possibly a witch or someone with supernatural abilities, which caused their fear and nervous reactions.

!" was her mama's cry; but she swept past her in stately silence, passed through the door which Colonel Dent held open, and we heard her enter the library.
A comparative silence ensued. Lady Ingram thought it "le cas" to wring her hands: which she did accordingly. Miss Mary declared she felt, for her part, she never dared venture. Amy and Louisa Eshton tittered under their breath, and looked a little frightened.
The minutes passed very slowly: fifteen were counted before the library- door again opened. Miss Ingram returned to us through the arch.
Would she laugh? Would she take it as a joke? All eyes met her with a glance of eager curiosity, and she met all eyes with one of rebuff and coldness; she looked neither flurried nor merry: she walked stiffly to her seat, and took it in silence.
"Well, Blanche?" said Lord Ingram.
"What did she say, sister?" asked Mary.
"What did you think? How do you feel?--Is she a real fortune-teller?" demanded the

nearly half-an-hour: during all that time she never turned a page, and her face grew momently darker, more dissatisfied, and more sourly expressive of disappointment. She had obviously not heard anything to her advantage: and it seemed to me, from her prolonged fit of gloom and taciturnity, that she herself, notwithstanding her professed indifference, attached undue importance to whatever revelations had been made her.
{During all that time she never turned a page: p184.jpg}
Meantime, Mary Ingram, Amy and Louisa Eshton, declared they dared not go alone; and yet they all wished to go. A negotiation was opened through the medium of the ambassador, Sam; and after much pacing to and fro, till, I think, the said Sam's calves must have ached with the exercise, permission was at last, with great difficulty, extorted from the rigorous Sibyl, for the three to wait upon her in a body.
Their visit was not so still as Miss Ingram's had been: we heard hysterical giggling and little shrieks proceeding from the library; and

Their visit was not so still as Miss Ingram's had been: we heard hysterical giggling and little shrieks proceeding from the library; and at the end of about twenty minutes they burst the door open, and came running across the hall, as if they were half-scared out of their wits.
"I am sure she is something not right!" they cried, one and all. "She told us such things! She knows all about us!" and they sank breathless into the various seats the gentlemen hastened to bring them.
Pressed for further explanation, they declared she had told them of things they had said and done when they were mere children; described books and ornaments they had in their boudoirs at home: keepsakes that different relations had presented to them. They affirmed that she had even divined their thoughts, and had whispered in the ear of each the name of the person she liked best in the world, and informed them of what they most wished for.
Here the gentlemen interposed with earnest petitions to be further enlightened on these two last-named points; but they got only blushes, e

?" asked Mary.
"What did you think? How do you feel?--Is she a real fortune-teller?" demanded the Misses Eshton.
"Now, now, good people," returned Miss Ingram, "don't press upon me. Really your organs of wonder and credulity are easily excited: you seem, by the importance of you all--my good mama included--ascribe to this matter, absolutely to believe we have a genuine witch in the house, who is in close alliance with the old gentleman. I have seen a gipsy vagabond; she has practised in hackneyed fashion the science of palmistry and told me what such people usually tell. My whim is gratified; and now I think Mr. Eshton will do well to put the hag in the stocks to-morrow morning, as he threatened."
Miss Ingram took a book, leant back in her chair, and so declined further conversation. I watched her for nearly half-an-hour: during all that time she never turned a page, and her face grew momently darker, more dissatisfied

ort in solemn conferences, where they nodded their two turbans at each other, and held up their four hands in confronting gestures of surprise, or mystery, or horror, according to the theme on which their gossip ran, like a pair of magnified puppets. Mild Mrs. Dent talked with good-natured Mrs. Eshton; and the two sometimes bestowed a courteous word or smile on me. Sir George Lynn, Colonel Dent, and Mr. Eshton discussed politics, or county affairs, or justice business. Lord Ingram flirted with Amy Eshton; Louisa played and sang to and with one of the Messrs. Lynn; and Mary Ingram listened languidly to the gallant speeches of the other. Sometimes all, as with one consent, suspended their by-play to observe and listen to the principal actors: for, after all, Mr. Rochester and--because closely connected with him--Miss Ingram were the life and soul of the party. If he was absent from the room an hour, a perceptible dulness seemed to steal over the spirits of his guests; and his re-entrance

Ere long a bell tinkled, and the curtain drew up. Within the arch, the bulky figure of Sir George Lynn, whom Mr. Rochester had likewise chosen, was seen enveloped in a white sheet: before him, on a table, lay open a large book; and at his side stood Amy Eshton, draped in Mr. Rochester's cloak, and holding a book in her hand. Somebody, unseen, rang the bell merrily; then Adele (who had insisted on being one of her guardian's party), bounded forward, scattering round her the contents of a basket of flowers she carried on her arm. Then appeared the magnificent figure of Miss Ingram, clad in white, a long veil on her head, and a wreath of roses round her brow; by her side walked Mr. Rochester, and together they drew near the table. They knelt; while Mrs. Dent and Louisa Eshton, dressed also in white, took up their stations behind them. A ceremony followed,

In this social gathering, the characters play different roles that contribute to the overall atmosphere of the event. Mr. Rochester and Miss Ingram are the central figures around whom the gathering revolves. Mr. Rochester's "extreme pallor" earlier in the evening suggests that he might have been anxious or worried about something, but his stern and firm appearance after drinking from the wine-glass indicates that he has regained his composure.
Mr. Rochester's presence is commanding, and he takes the lead in organizing the charades, selecting certain ladies to be on his team. He specifically chooses Miss Ingram, who is portrayed as a regal and captivating figure, often inclining her head towards Mr. Rochester and whispering to him, further emphasizing their connection and attraction.
The other characters, such as Colonel Dent, Mrs. Dent, and the Misses Eshton, form smaller groups and engage in lively conversations and laughter, contributing to the high spirits of the gathering. Mr. Mason, who was initially thought to be melancholic, also appears to be in good spirits, engaging in conversation with Colonel and Mrs. Dent.
The atmosphere of the group is significantly affected by Mr. Rochester and Miss Ingram's presence, as they are the focus of attention and interest. Their interactions suggest an impending marriage, which might be a topic of discussion and speculation among the other guests. The jovial and animated atmosphere of the gathering also highlights the social dynamics of the group, where individuals engage with one another based on their connections, interests, and shared social status.
Overall, the various characters play roles that contribute to the social hierarchy and dynamics of the gathering, with Mr. Rochester and Miss Ingram at the center, influencing the atmosphere through their interactions and presence.

"Now, Dent," continued Mr. Rochester, "it is your turn." And as the other party withdrew, he and his band took the vacated seats. Miss Ingram placed herself at her leader's right hand; the other diviners filled the chairs on each side of him and her. I did not now watch the actors; I no longer waited with interest for the curtain to rise; my attention was absorbed by the spectators; my eyes, erewhile fixed on the arch, were now irresistibly attracted to the semicircle of chairs. What charade Colonel Dent and his party played, what word they chose, how they acquitted themselves, I no longer remember; but I still see the consultation which followed each scene: I see Mr. Rochester turn to Miss Ingram, and Miss Ingram to him; I see her incline her head towards him, till the jetty curls almost touch his shoulder and wave against his cheek; I hear their mutual whisperings; I recall their interchanged glances; and something even of the feeling roused by the spectacle returns in memory at this moment.

said; they were not seated at table,--the supper was arranged on the sideboard; each had taken what he chose, and they stood about here and there in groups, their plates and glasses in their hands. Every one seemed in high glee; laughter and conversation were general and animated. Mr. Mason stood near the fire, talking to Colonel and Mrs. Dent, and appeared as merry as any of them. I filled a wine-glass (I saw Miss Ingram watch me frowningly as I did so: she thought I was taking a liberty, I daresay), and I returned to the library.
Mr. Rochester's extreme pallor had disappeared, and he looked once more firm and stern. He took the glass from my hand.
"Here is to your health, ministrant spirit!" he said. He swallowed the contents and returned it to me. "What are they doing, Jane?"
"Laughing and talking, sir."
"They don't look grave and mysterious, as if they had heard something strange?"

will she manage to please him when they are married? I do not think she will manage it; and yet it might be managed; and his wife might, I verily believe, be the very happiest woman the sun shines on."
I have not yet said anything condemnatory of Mr. Rochester's project of marrying for interest and connections. It surprised me when I first discovered that such was his intention: I had thought him a man unlikely to be influenced by motives so commonplace in his choice of a wife; but the longer I considered the position, education, &c., of the parties, the less I felt justified in judging and blaming either him or Miss Ingram for acting in conformity to ideas and principles instilled into them, doubtless, from their childhood. All their class held these principles: I supposed, then, they had reasons for holding them such as I could not fathom. It seemed to me that, were I a gentleman like him, I would take to my bosom only such a wife as I could love; but the very obviousness of the advantages to the husband's own happiness offered by this plan convinced me that

were carried to the boudoir within the drawing-room.
Meantime, Mr. Rochester had again summoned the ladies round him, and was selecting certain of their number to be of his party. "Miss Ingram is mine, of course," said he: afterwards he named the two Misses Eshton, and Mrs. Dent. He looked at me: I happened to be near him, as I had been fastening the clasp of Mrs. Dent's bracelet, which had got loose.
"Will you play?" he asked. I shook my head. He did not insist, which I rather feared he would have done; he allowed me to return quietly to my usual seat.
He and his aids now withdrew behind the curtain: the other party, which was headed by Colonel Dent, sat down on the crescent of chairs. One of the gentlemen, Mr. Eshton, observing me, seemed to propose that I should be asked to join them; but Lady Ingram instantly negatived the notion.
"No," I heard her say: "she looks too stupid for any game of the sort."

I were in fault.
Some parleying was audible in the hall, and soon the new-comer entered. He bowed to Lady Ingram, as deeming her the eldest lady present.
"It appears I come at an inopportune time, madam," said he, "when my friend, Mr. Rochester, is from home; but I arrive from a very long journey, and I think I may presume so far on old and intimate acquaintance as to instal myself here till he returns."
His manner was polite; his accent, in speaking, struck me as being somewhat unusual,--not precisely foreign, but still not altogether English: his age might be about Mr. Rochester's,--between thirty and forty; his complexion was singularly sallow: otherwise he was a fine-looking man, at first sight especially. On closer examination, you detected something in his face that displeased, or rather that failed to please. His features were regular, but too relaxed: his eye was large and well cut, but the life looking out of it was a tame, vacant life--at least so I thought.

"Mr. Rochester has a right to enjoy the society of his guests."
"No question about his right: but have you never observed that, of all the tales told here about matrimony, Mr. Rochester has been favoured with the most lively and the most continuous?"
"The eagerness of a listener quickens the tongue of a narrator." I said this rather to myself than to the gipsy, whose strange talk, voice, manner, had by this time wrapped me in a kind of dream. One unexpected sentence came from her lips after another, till I got involved in a web of mystification; and wondered what unseen spirit had been sitting for weeks by my heart watching its workings and taking record of every pulse.

In response to Mr. Rochester's instructions, the narrator (Jane Eyre) carried out the following actions:
1. She approached Mr. Mason and whispered in his ear that Mr. Rochester was here and wished to see him. 2. She escorted Mr. Mason to the library where Mr. Rochester was waiting. 3. After ensuring Mr. Mason was received by Mr. Rochester, she left the room and went upstairs to her own chamber.
These actions demonstrated Jane's loyalty and willingness to follow Mr. Rochester's wishes in several ways:
1. She did not question Mr. Rochester's instructions or hesitate to carry them out, showing her trust and obedience towards him. 2. She executed the tasks with confidence and determination, moving "straight among" the company and leading Mr. Mason to the library without hesitation. 3. Her loyalty was also revealed through her concern for Mr. Rochester's well-being, as she felt relieved and went to sleep only after hearing his cheerful voice and knowing he was safe and sound.
Overall, Jane's actions demonstrated her strong sense of loyalty, obedience, and care for Mr. Rochester, further solidifying their bond as employer and employee and hinting at her deeper feelings for him.

she never offered, nor had, an opinion of her own. She advocated a high tone of sentiment; but she did not know the sensations of sympathy and pity; tenderness and truth were not in her. Too often she betrayed this, by the undue vent she gave to a spiteful antipathy she had conceived against little Adele: pushing her away with some contumelious epithet if she happened to approach her; sometimes ordering her from the room, and always treating her with coldness and acrimony. Other eyes besides mine watched these manifestations of character--watched them closely, keenly, shrewdly. Yes; the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself, exercised over his intended a ceaseless surveillance; and it was from this sagacity--this guardedness of his--this perfect, clear consciousness of his fair one's defects--this obvious absence of passion in his sentiments towards her, that my ever- torturing pain arose.
I saw he was going to marry her, for family, perhaps political reasons, because her rank and connections suited him; I felt he had not given her his love

if I did, I should care nothing about it."
"Then, you could dare censure for my sake?"
"I could dare it for the sake of any friend who deserved my adherence; as you, I am sure, do."
"Go back now into the room; step quietly up to Mason, and whisper in his ear that Mr. Rochester is come and wishes to see him: show him in here and then leave me."
"Yes, sir."
I did his behest. The company all stared at me as I passed straight among them. I sought Mr. Mason, delivered the message, and preceded him from the room: I ushered him into the library, and then I went upstairs.
At a late hour, after I had been in bed some time, I heard the visitors repair to their chambers: I distinguished Mr. Rochester's voice, and heard him say, "This way, Mason; this is your room."
He spoke cheerfully: the gay tones set my heart at ease. I was soon asleep.

Jane Eyre cannot manage to please Mr. Rochester and become the happiest woman in the world by trying to fit into his project of marrying for interest and connections. The reason is that she doesn't have the social status or wealth that he is looking for in a wife. Moreover, it is clear that Jane and Mr. Rochester are well-suited to each other because of their intellectual equality and mutual respect, which go beyond social standings and financial gains.
To become Mr. Rochester's wife and potentially the happiest woman in the world, Jane needs to be true to herself and follow her heart. She must show Mr. Rochester that she can be a partner to him in every sense, not just a socially acceptable wife. Jane has already shown her loyalty, obedience, and care for Mr. Rochester, which are essential qualities for a successful marriage. However, she must also express her feelings for him and make him see that their love goes beyond social conventions.
In the end, Jane does manage to please Mr. Rochester and become the happiest woman in the world, but not by trying to fit into his original plan of marrying for interest and connections. Instead, she stays true to herself and follows her heart, which leads her to a deeper and more meaningful relationship with Mr. Rochester.

admiration--the more truly tranquil my quiescence. But as matters really stood, to watch Miss Ingram's efforts at fascinating Mr. Rochester, to witness their repeated failure--herself unconscious that they did fail; vainly fancying that each shaft launched hit the mark, and infatuatedly pluming herself on success, when her pride and self-complacency repelled further and further what she wished to allure--to witness _this_, was to be at once under ceaseless excitation and ruthless restraint.
Because, when she failed, I saw how she might have succeeded. Arrows that continually glanced off from Mr. Rochester's breast and fell harmless at his feet, might, I knew, if shot by a surer hand, have quivered keen in his proud heart--have called love into his stern eye, and softness into his sardonic face; or, better still, without weapons a silent conquest might have been won.
"Why can she not influence him more, when she is privileged to draw so near to him?" I asked myself. "Surely she cannot truly like him, or not

I said nothing.

interchanged glances; and something even of the feeling roused by the spectacle returns in memory at this moment.
I have told you, reader, that I had learnt to love Mr. Rochester: I could not unlove him now, merely because I found that he had ceased to notice me--because I might pass hours in his presence, and he would never once turn his eyes in my direction--because I saw all his attentions appropriated by a great lady, who scorned to touch me with the hem of her robes as she passed; who, if ever her dark and imperious eye fell on me by chance, would withdraw it instantly as from an object too mean to merit observation. I could not unlove him, because I felt sure he would soon marry this very lady--because I read daily in her a proud security in his intentions respecting her--because I witnessed hourly in him a style of courtship which, if careless and choosing rather to be sought than to seek, was yet, in its very carelessness, captivating, and in its very pride, irresistible.
There was nothing to cool or banish love in these circumstances, though

The tall, fashionable-looking man who arrived in a post-chaise is named Mason, and he comes from the West Indies, specifically from Spanish Town in Jamaica. When Mr. Rochester left in the morning, he was riding Mesrour, his black horse, and Pilot, his dog was with him. However, when Mason arrived, there was no sign of Mesrour or Pilot, which made Miss Ingram exclaim, "What has he done with the animals?"

smile signify?"
"Wonder and self-congratulation, sir. I have your permission to retire now, I suppose?"
"No; stay a moment; and tell me what the people in the drawing-room yonder are doing."
"Discussing the gipsy, I daresay."
"Sit down!--Let me hear what they said about me."
"I had better not stay long, sir; it must be near eleven o'clock. Oh, are you aware, Mr. Rochester, that a stranger has arrived here since you left this morning?"
"A stranger!--no; who can it be? I expected no one; is he gone?"
"No; he said he had known you long, and that he could take the liberty of installing himself here till you returned."
"The devil he did! Did he give his name?"
"His name is Mason, sir; and he comes from the West Indies; from Spanish Town, in Jamaica, I think."
Mr. Rochester was standing near me; he had taken my hand, as if to lead me to a chair.

"What can possess him to come home in that style?" said Miss Ingram. "He rode Mesrour (the black horse), did he not, when he went out? and Pilot was with him:--what has he done with the animals?"
As she said this, she approached her tall person and ample garments so near the window, that I was obliged to bend back almost to the breaking of my spine: in her eagerness she did not observe me at first, but when she did, she curled her lip and moved to another casement. The post-chaise stopped; the driver rang the door-bell, and a gentleman alighted attired in travelling garb; but it was not Mr. Rochester; it was a tall, fashionable-looking man, a stranger.
"How provoking!" exclaimed Miss Ingram: "you tiresome monkey!" (apostrophising Adele), "who perched you up in the window to give false intelligence?" and she cast on me an angry glance, as if I were in fault.

"You don't know the gentlemen here? You have not exchanged a syllable with one of them? Will you say that of the master of the house!"
"He is not at home."

"Do you know," said she, "that, of the three characters, I liked you in the last best? Oh, had you but lived a few years earlier, what a gallant gentleman-highwayman you would have made!"
"Is all the soot washed from my face?" he asked, turning it towards her.
"Alas! yes: the more's the pity! Nothing could be more becoming to your complexion than that ruffian's rouge."
"You would like a hero of the road then?"
"An English hero of the road would be the next best thing to an Italian bandit; and that could only be surpassed by a Levantine pirate."
"Well, whatever I am, remember you are my wife; we were married an hour since, in the presence of all these witnesses." She giggled, and her colour rose.

light of the girandoles on the mantelpiece beaming full over him--for he occupied an arm-chair drawn close to the fire, and kept shrinking still nearer, as if he were cold, I compared him with Mr. Rochester. I think (with deference be it spoken) the contrast could not be much greater between a sleek gander and a fierce falcon: between a meek sheep and the rough-coated keen-eyed dog, its guardian.
He had spoken of Mr. Rochester as an old friend. A curious friendship theirs must have been: a pointed illustration, indeed, of the old adage that "extremes meet."
Two or three of the gentlemen sat near him, and I caught at times scraps of their conversation across the room. At first I could not make much sense of what I heard; for the discourse of Louisa Eshton and Mary Ingram, who sat nearer to me, confused the fragmentary sentences that reached me at intervals. by a screen, hung with some sort of dark and coarse drapery. The marble basin was removed; in its place, stood a deal table and a kitchen chair: these objects were visible by a very dim light proceeding from a horn lantern, the wax candles being all extinguished.
Amidst this sordid scene, sat a man with his clenched hands resting on his knees, and his eyes bent on the ground. I knew Mr. Rochester; though the begrimed face, the disordered dress (his coat hanging loose from one arm, as if it had been almost torn from his back in a scuffle), the desperate and scowling countenance, the rough, bristling hair might well have disguised him. As he moved, a chain clanked; to his wrists were attached fetters.
"Bridewell!" exclaimed Colonel Dent, and the charade was solved.
A sufficient interval having elapsed for the performers to resume their ordinary costume, they re-entered the dining-room. Mr. Rochester led in Miss Ingram; she was complimenting him on his acting.

tunes and airs on the piano, and then, having fetched a novel from the library, had flung herself in haughty listlessness on a sofa, and prepared to beguile, by the spell of fiction, the tedious hours of absence. The room and the house were silent: only now and then the merriment of the billiard-players was heard from above.
It was verging on dusk, and the clock had already given warning of the hour to dress for dinner, when little Adele, who knelt by me in the drawing-room window-seat, suddenly exclaimed--
"Voila, Monsieur Rochester, qui revient!"
I turned, and Miss Ingram darted forwards from her sofa: the others, too, looked up from their several occupations; for at the same time a crunching of wheels and a splashing tramp of horse-hoofs became audible on the wet gravel. A post-chaise was approaching.

at least curiosity?"
"I like to observe all the faces and all the figures."
"But do you never single one from the rest--or it may be, two?"
"I do frequently; when the gestures or looks of a pair seem telling a tale: it amuses me to watch them."
"What tale do you like best to hear?"
"Oh, I have not much choice! They generally run on the same theme--courtship; and promise to end in the same catastrophe--marriage."
"And do you like that monotonous theme?"
"Positively, I don't care about it: it is nothing to me."
"Nothing to you? When a lady, young and full of life and health, charming with beauty and endowed with the gifts of rank and fortune, sits and smiles in the eyes of a gentleman you--"
"I what?"
"You know--and perhaps think well of."
"I don't know the gentlemen here. I have scarcely interchanged a syllable with one of them; and as to thinking well of them, I consider some respectable,

influence him more, when she is privileged to draw so near to him?" I asked myself. "Surely she cannot truly like him, or not like him with true affection! If she did, she need not coin her smiles so lavishly, flash her glances so unremittingly, manufacture airs so elaborate, graces so multitudinous. It seems to me that she might, by merely sitting quietly at his side, saying little and looking less, get nigher his heart. I have seen in his face a far different expression from that which hardens it now while she is so vivaciously accosting him; but then it came of itself: it was not elicited by meretricious arts and calculated manoeuvres; and one had but to accept it--to answer what he asked without pretension, to address him when needful without grimace--and it increased and grew kinder and more genial, and warmed one like a fostering sunbeam. How will she manage to please him when they are married? I do not think she will manage it; and yet it might be managed; and his

I was now able to concentrate my attention on the group by the fire, and I presently gathered that the new-comer was called Mr. Mason; then I learned that he was but just arrived in England, and that he came from some hot country: which was the reason, doubtless, his face was so sallow, and that he sat so near the hearth, and wore a surtout in the house. After the fortune-telling scene with the mysterious woman in the library, Miss Ingram and the others had varying reactions. Miss Ingram returned from the library with a cold and stiff demeanor, not revealing anything about what the fortune-teller had said. She dismissed the experience as an ordinary palm reading and suggested that Mr. Eshton should put the fortune-teller in the stocks the next morning. However, her reaction was likely a cover-up, as she grew momently darker and more dissatisfied, not turning a page of her book for nearly half an hour.
The Misses Eshton and Mary Ingram, on the other hand, were quite shaken by the experience. They claimed that the fortune-teller knew a lot of personal details about them, such as things they had said and done when they were children, books and ornaments in their boudoirs, keepsakes presented by different relations, and even their thoughts and desires. They were so frightened that they ran across the hall, sinking breathlessly into the chairs provided by the gentlemen.
Despite the gentlemen's earnest petitions, Miss Ingram and the others did not reveal the specifics of what the fortune-teller had whispered in their ears regarding the person they liked best in the world and what they most wished for. It can be inferred that the fortune-teller had accurately revealed some intimate details, causing the ladies to be both amazed and frightened.
As for Miss Ingram's private conversation with Mr. Rochester during the charade that followed, the narrator, Jane, did not provide any specific details. However, Jane did mention that she still sees the consultation which followed each scene, with Mr. Rochester turning to Miss Ingram, and Miss Ingram inclining her head towards him, till the jetty curls almost touch his shoulder and wave against his cheek. She also recalls their mutual whisperings and interchanged glances, indicating that there was a strong attraction and connection between the two during that time.

The observer, who is the narrator, Jane Eyre, is trying to understand the depths of Mr. Rochester's feelings and intentions regarding his impending marriage to Miss Ingram. Jane is both fearful and curious because she senses that there is more to Mr. Rochester's motivations than meets the eye, and she is uncertain about what she might discover. The rest of the party, including Mr. Rochester himself, seems to be preoccupied with their own interests and pleasures, leaving Jane free to observe and analyze their interactions. However, this also makes Jane feel isolated and somewhat anxious, as she is not fully part of the group and is instead an outsider looking in. The "strange depths" of Mr. Rochester's eye may refer to the complexity and mystery of his character, which Jane is trying to decipher.

Based on the narrative, Miss Ingram can be described as lacking originality, insincere, and having limited intellect. She is portrayed as someone who repeats sounding phrases from books and never offers or has an opinion of her own. Her mind is described as poor and her heart as barren by nature. She is shown to be more concerned with appearances and social status than genuine emotions or relationships. The narrator, Jane Eyre, finds it difficult to describe her pain as jealousy because she believes that Miss Ingram is not a worthy object of such a feeling. Jane feels that Miss Ingram is not good, not genuine, and not capable of charming Mr. Rochester in a meaningful way. Therefore, Jane's emotional response to the situation is more complex than simple jealousy.

There was nothing to cool or banish love in these circumstances, though much to create despair. Much too, you will think, reader, to engender jealousy: if a woman, in my position, could presume to be jealous of a woman in Miss Ingram's. But I was not jealous: or very rarely;--the nature of the pain I suffered could not be explained by that word. Miss Ingram was a mark beneath jealousy: she was too inferior to excite the feeling. Pardon the seeming paradox; I mean what I say. She was very showy, but she was not genuine: she had a fine person, many brilliant attainments; but her mind was poor, her heart barren by nature: nothing bloomed spontaneously on that soil; no unforced natural fruit delighted by its freshness. She was not good; she was not original: she used to repeat sounding phrases from books: she never offered, nor had, an opinion of her own. Sam went and returned.

It is natural to find it difficult to stop loving someone once you have developed feelings for them, even if they are ignoring you or paying attention to someone else. In the narrative provided, Jane Eyre, the protagonist, has learned to love Mr. Rochester, and she cannot stop doing so even when he ignores her and showers his attentions on another woman, Miss Ingram. This is because the feeling of love is not solely based on reciprocation or attention; it is also influenced by the emotional connection, respect, and admiration that Jane has for Mr. Rochester.
Furthermore, Jane's love for Mr. Rochester is not dependent on his careless and prideful courtship of Miss Ingram. Instead, Jane recognizes the superficiality of their relationship and believes that she could have succeeded in winning his heart if she had approached him differently. However, Jane's love for Mr. Rochester is not based on manipulation or strategy; it is grounded in her genuine appreciation for his personality and their intellectual equality.
Therefore, even though Mr. Rochester is ignoring Jane and paying attention to someone else, she cannot stop loving him because her feelings are based on a deeper connection that goes beyond social conventions and external displays of affection.

The gipsy's observations about Mr. Rochester's happiness being "carefully laid" aside for him and depending on his own actions to "stretch out his hand, and take it up" are based on her interpretations of his facial expressions and behavior. The gipsy seems to have a keen sense of observation and a belief that people's true feelings and emotions can be read through their gestures, looks, and eyes.
When the gipsy observes Mr. Rochester's eyes, she notes that they "shine like dew" and are "soft and full of feeling," indicating a susceptible and emotional nature. She also interprets his "unconscious lassitude" and "melancholy resulting from loneliness" as signs of his inner longing and dissatisfaction with his current situation.
The gipsy's belief that Mr. Rochester's happiness depends on his own actions suggests that she sees him as having the power to choose his own path and create his own happiness, rather than being passive and waiting for it to come to him. This interpretation is consistent with the gipsy's earlier statement that she likes to observe people and study their gestures and looks, as if she is trying to understand their true motivations and desires.
The physical discomfort that Mr. Rochester feels from kneeling too close to the fire is separate from the happiness that the gipsy is referring to. While Mr. Rochester may experience physical discomfort, the gipsy is suggesting that he also has the potential for deeper emotional fulfillment if he chooses to pursue it.
Overall, the gipsy's observations and interpretations are based on her ability to read people's emotions and motivations through their gestures, looks, and behavior. While her interpretations may not be entirely accurate, they suggest that she sees Mr. Rochester as a complex and multifaceted individual who has the power to create his own happiness if he chooses to do so.

Mr. Rochester has a sudden reaction and exclaims about Mason and the West Indies because he has just heard that a man named Mason, who comes from the West Indies, has arrived at the house. This information triggers a spasm and distress in Mr. Rochester, possibly because he has a hidden connection or history with this person related to the West Indies.

However, when Mason arrived, there was no sign of Mesrour or Pilot. This led to Miss Ingram's exclamation of surprise and annoyance, as she wondered what had happened to Mr. Rochester's animals. Additionally, Mason's arrival was not the news that Adele had reported, which is why Miss Ingram chided her and glanced angrily at the narrator.

Mr. Rochester's forgiveness is dependent on whether or not he finds he has committed a "great absurdity" in his interaction with the speaker because he is unsure if he has offended or upset her with his behavior. He may have sensed some distance or change in her demeanor and is trying to gauge if he has done anything wrong.
The speaker is both wondering and feeling self-congratulatory as they request to retire because they have successfully uncovered Mr. Rochester's plans to marry Miss Ingram, and they are satisfied with their own observational skills and ability to interpret social cues. At the same time, they are also feeling a mix of emotions, including confusion and uncertainty about their own feelings towards Mr. Rochester and their relationship with him, which is why they are wondering about their reaction to his behavior.

The primary challenge for the narrator, Jane Eyre, in regard to Mr. Rochester's relationship with Miss Ingram is the disparity between her own feelings for Mr. Rochester and the reality of his impending marriage to Miss Ingram. Jane is deeply in love with Mr. Rochester, but she recognizes that Miss Ingram is the more likely candidate for marriage due to her social status and connections. However, Jane does not experience the same intense emotions of jealousy or resentment towards Miss Ingram that she might have under different circumstances. This is because Jane perceives Miss Ingram as lacking in originality, insincerity, and limited intellect, and therefore views her as an unworthy object of jealousy. Jane believes that Miss Ingram is not good or genuine, and that she cannot charm Mr. Rochester in a meaningful way. Consequently, Jane's emotional response to the situation is more complex than simple jealousy.
Moreover, the narrative suggests that Mr. Rochester is marrying Miss Ingram primarily for reasons of interest and connections, rather than out of love. This further diminishes the romantic nature of their relationship in Jane's eyes. While Mr. Rochester and Miss Ingram do share a strong attraction and connection, their behavior during the charade performance suggests a flirtatious and romantic dynamic, rather than a deep emotional bond or love. Mr. Rochester is aware of Miss Ingram's superficiality and lack of originality, and yet still plans to marry her, suggesting that he values her social status and connections more than her personality or character.
Therefore, Jane's challenge is not only to come to terms with her own feelings of love and jealousy, but also to recognize the limitations and superficiality of Mr. Rochester's relationship with Miss Ingram. Jane's emotional response is shaped by her own moral and intellectual values, which lead her to view Miss Ingram as an unworthy object of jealousy, and Mr. Rochester's relationship with her as lacking in depth and genuine affection.

Meantime, Mary Ingram, Amy and Louisa Eshton, declared they dared not go alone; and yet they all wished to go. Their visit was not so still as Miss Ingram's had been: we heard hysterical giggling and little shrieks proceeding from the library; and at the end of about twenty minutes they burst the door open, and came running across the hall, as if they were half-scared out of their wits.
"I am sure she is something not right!" they cried, one and all. "She told us such things! She knows all about us!" and they sank breathless into the various seats the gentlemen hastened to bring them.
Pressed for further explanation, they declared she had told them of things they had said and done when they were mere children; described books and ornaments they had in their boudoirs at home: keepsakes that different relations had presented to them. They affirmed that she had even divined their thoughts, and had whispered in the ear of each the name of the person she liked best in the world, and informed them of what they most wished for.
Here the gentlemen interposed with earnest petitions to be further enlightened on these two last-named points; but they got only blushes, e

?" asked Mary.
"What did you think? How do you feel?--Is she a real fortune-teller?" demanded the Misses Eshton.
"Now, now, good people," returned Miss Ingram, "don't press upon me. Really your organs of wonder and credulity are easily excited: you seem, by the importance of you all--my good mama included--ascribe to this matter, absolutely to believe we have a genuine witch in the house, who is in close alliance with the old gentleman. I have seen a gipsy vagabond; she has practised in hackneyed fashion the science of palmistry and told me what such people usually tell. My whim is gratified; and now I think Mr. Eshton will do well to put the hag in the stocks to-morrow morning, as he threatened."

edge.target: ort in solemn conferences, where they nodded their two turbans at each other, and held up their four hands in confronting gestures of surprise, or mystery, or horror, according to the theme on which their gossip ran, like a pair of magnified puppets. Mild Mrs. Dent talked with good-natured Mrs. Eshton; and the two sometimes bestowed a courteous word or smile on me. Sir George Lynn, Colonel Dent, and Mr. Eshton discussed politics, or county affairs, or justice business. Lord Ingram flirted with Amy Eshton; Louisa played and sang to and with one of the Messrs. Lynn; and Mary Ingram listened languidly to the gallant speeches of the other. Sometimes all, as with one consent, suspended their by-play to observe and listen to the principal actors: for, after all, Mr. Rochester and--because closely connected with him--Miss Ingram were the life and soul of the party. If he was absent from the room an hour, a perceptible dulness seemed to steal over the spirits of his guests; and his re-entrance

Ere long a bell tinkled, and the curtain drew up. Within the arch, the bulky figure of Sir George Lynn, whom Mr. Rochester had likewise chosen, was seen enveloped in a white sheet: before him, on a table, lay open a large book; and at his side stood Amy Eshton, draped in Mr. Rochester's cloak, and holding a book in her hand. Somebody, unseen, rang the bell merrily; then Adele (who had insisted on being one of her guardian's party), bounded forward, scattering round her the contents of a basket of flowers she carried on her arm. Then appeared the magnificent figure of Miss Ingram, clad in white, a long veil on her head, and a wreath of roses round her brow; by her side walked Mr. Rochester, and together they drew near the table. They knelt; while Mrs. Dent and Louisa Eshton, dressed also in white, took up their stations behind them. A ceremony followed,

edge.source: Mary Ingram, Amy, and Louisa Eshton required permission from Miss Ingram to visit the library because she was the one who had initially gone to see the fortune-teller and they were afraid to go alone. The nervous reactions inside the library could be attributed to the fact that the fortune-teller seemed to know a lot of personal details about them, such as things they had said and done when they were children, books and ornaments in their boudoirs, keepsakes presented by different relations, and even their thoughts and desires. This accurate and specific information made them believe that the fortune-teller was not an ordinary person but possibly a witch or someone with supernatural abilities, which caused their fear and nervous reactions.
edge.target:
After the fortune-telling scene with the mysterious woman in the library, Miss Ingram and the others had varying reactions. Miss Ingram returned from the library with a cold and stiff demeanor, not revealing anything about what the fortune-teller had said. She dismissed the experience as an ordinary palm reading and suggested that Mr. Eshton should put the fortune-teller in the stocks the next morning. However, her reaction was likely a cover-up, as she grew momently darker and more dissatisfied, not turning a page of her book for nearly half an hour.
The Misses Eshton and Mary Ingram, on the other hand, were quite shaken by the experience. They claimed that the fortune-teller knew a lot of personal details about them, such as things they had said and done when they were children, books and ornaments in their boudoirs, keepsakes presented by different relations, and even their thoughts and desires. They were so frightened that they ran across the hall, sinking breathlessly into the chairs provided by the gentlemen.
Despite the gentlemen's earnest petitions, Miss Ingram and the others did not reveal the specifics of what the fortune-teller had whispered in their ears regarding the person they liked best in the world and what they most wished for. It can be inferred that the fortune-teller had accurately revealed some intimate details, causing the ladies to be both amazed and frightened.
As for Miss Ingram's private conversation with Mr. Rochester during the charade that followed, the narrator, Jane, did not provide any specific details. However, Jane did mention that she still sees the consultation which followed each scene, with Mr. Rochester turning to Miss Ingram, and Miss Ingram inclining her head towards him, till the jetty curls almost touch his shoulder and wave against his cheek. She also recalls their mutual whisperings and interchanged glances, indicating that there was a strong attraction and connection between the two during that time.

Jane feels that Miss Ingram is not good, not genuine, and not capable of charming Mr. Rochester in a meaningful way. Therefore, Jane's emotional response to the situation is more complex than simple jealousy.

edge.target:
The ladies should handle the persistent old fortune-teller by setting clear boundaries and standing firm. They initially try to persuade her to leave, but when she refuses, they should not give in to the pressure from the men to encourage her stay. Mrs. Lynn and the Dowager Ingram object to the idea, and the footman reports that the fortune-teller is "quite troublesome." Mr. Eshton even threatens to put her in the stocks. However, Blanche Ingram insists on having her fortune told, and the other ladies follow her lead.
When the fortune-teller refuses to see anyone except the young and single ladies, Blanche takes charge and insists on seeing her alone in the library. The other ladies are hesitant, but Blanche's insistence wins out.
In the end, Blanche returns from the library looking serious and cold, indicating that the encounter may not have gone as she expected. The ladies could have avoided this situation by being more firm in their initial objections and refusing to indulge in the "running fire of raillery and jests" at the fortune-teller's expense.

I have seen a gipsy vagabond; she has practised in hackneyed fashion the science of palmistry and told me what such people usually tell. My whim is gratified; and now I think Mr. Eshton will do well to put the hag in the stocks to-morrow morning, as he threatened."
Miss Ingram took a book, leant back in her chair, and so declined further conversation. I watched her for nearly half-an-hour: during all that time she never turned a page, and her face grew momently darker, more dissatisfied
edge.target:
After the fortune-telling session in the library, Miss Ingram returned with a cold and stiff demeanor, dismissing the experience as an ordinary palm reading. However, she grew darker and more dissatisfied, not turning a page of her book for nearly half an hour. The Misses Eshton and Mary Ingram, on the other hand, were quite shaken and claimed that the fortune-teller knew personal details about them. They were so frightened that they ran across the hall and sunk breathlessly into the chairs provided by the gentlemen. Despite the gentlemen's petitions, the ladies did not reveal the specifics of what the fortune-teller had whispered in their ears.
The community's perception of Jane's abilities as a fortune-teller is not explicitly stated in the narrative. However, it is mentioned that the fortune-teller (who is revealed to be Mr. Rochester in disguise) seemed to know a lot of personal details about Miss Ingram and the others, which made them believe that she was not an ordinary person but possibly a witch or someone with supernatural abilities. This caused their fear and nervous reactions. When the tall, fashionable-looking man named Mason arrives, he assumes that Mr. Rochester is not at home because he is with his new wife, Miss Ingram, indicating that their marriage is a widely known fact.

edge.target:
"Now, Dent," continued Mr. Rochester, "it is your turn." And as the other party withdrew, he and his band took the vacated seats. Miss Ingram placed herself at her leader's right hand; the other diviners filled the chairs on each side of him and her. I did not now watch the actors; I no longer waited with interest for the curtain to rise; my attention was absorbed by the spectators; my eyes, erewhile fixed on the arch, were now irresistibly attracted to the semicircle of chairs. What charade Colonel Dent and his party played, what word they chose, how they acquitted themselves, I no longer remember; but I still see the consultation which followed each scene: I see Mr. Rochester turn to Miss Ingram, and Miss Ingram to him; I see her incline her head towards him, till the jetty curls almost touch his shoulder and wave against his cheek; I hear their mutual whisperings; I recall their interchanged glances; and something even of the feeling roused by the spectacle returns in memory at this moment.
I have told you

said; they were not seated at table,--the supper was arranged on the sideboard; each had taken what he chose, and they stood about here and there in groups, their plates and glasses in their hands. Every one seemed in high glee; laughter and conversation were general and animated. Mr. Mason stood near the fire, talking to Colonel and Mrs. Dent, and appeared as merry as any of them. I filled a wine-glass (I saw Miss Ingram watch me frowningly as I did so: she thought I was taking a liberty, I daresay), and I returned to the library.
Mr. Rochester's extreme pallor had disappeared, and he looked once more firm and stern. He took the glass from my hand.
"Here is to your health, ministrant spirit!" he said. He swallowed the contents and returned it to me. "What are they doing, Jane?"
"Laughing and talking, sir."
"They don't look grave and mysterious, as if they had heard something strange?"

will she manage to please him when they are married? I do not think she will manage it; and yet it might be managed; and his wife might, I verily believe, be the very happiest woman the sun shines on."
I have not yet said anything condemnatory of Mr. Rochester's project of marrying for interest and connections. It surprised me when I first discovered that such was his intention: I had thought him a man unlikely to be influenced by motives so commonplace in his choice of a wife; but the longer I considered the position, education, &c., of the parties, the less I felt justified in judging and blaming either him or Miss Ingram for acting in conformity to ideas and principles instilled into them, doubtless, from their childhood. All their class held these principles: I supposed, then, they had reasons for holding them such as I could not fathom. It seemed to me that, were I a gentleman like him, I would take to my bosom only such a wife as I could love; but the very obviousness of the advantages to the husband's own happiness offered by this plan convinced me that

Meantime, Mr. Rochester had again summoned the ladies round him, and was selecting certain of their number to be of his party. "Miss Ingram is mine, of course," said he: afterwards he named the two Misses Eshton, and Mrs. Dent. He looked at me: I happened to be near him, as I had been fastening the clasp of Mrs. Dent's bracelet, which had got loose.
"Will you play?" he asked. I shook my head. He did not insist, which I rather feared he would have done; he allowed me to return quietly to my usual seat.
He and his aids now withdrew behind the curtain: the other party, which was headed by Colonel Dent, sat down on the crescent of chairs. One of the gentlemen, Mr. Eshton, observing me, seemed to propose that I should be asked to join them; but Lady Ingram instantly negatived the notion.
"No," I heard her say: "she looks too stupid for any game of the sort."

I were in fault.
Some parleying was audible in the hall, and soon the new-comer entered. He bowed to Lady Ingram, as deeming her the eldest lady present.
"It appears I come at an inopportune time, madam," said he, "when my friend, Mr. Rochester, is from home; but I arrive from a very long journey, and I think I may presume so far on old and intimate acquaintance as to instal myself here till he returns."
His manner was polite; his accent, in speaking, struck me as being somewhat unusual,--not precisely foreign, but still not altogether English: his age might be about Mr. Rochester's,--between thirty and forty; his complexion was singularly sallow: otherwise he was a fine-looking man, at first sight especially. On closer examination, you detected something in his face that displeased, or rather that failed to please. His features were regular, but too relaxed: his eye was large and well cut, but the life looking out of it was a tame, vacant life--at least so I thought.

"I was talking of ladies smiling in the eyes of gentlemen; and of late so many smiles have been shed into Mr. Rochester's eyes that they overflow like two cups filled above the brim: have you never remarked that?"
"Mr. Rochester has a right to enjoy the society of his guests."
"No question about his right: but have you never observed that, of all the tales told here about matrimony, Mr. Rochester has been favoured with the most lively and the most continuous?"
"The eagerness of a listener quickens the tongue of a narrator." I said this rather to myself than to the gipsy, whose strange talk, voice, manner, had by this time wrapped me in a kind of dream. One unexpected sentence came from her lips after another, till I got involved in a web of mystification; and wondered what unseen spirit had been sitting for weeks by my heart watching its workings and taking record of every pulse.

In response to Mr. Rochester's instructions, the narrator (Jane Eyre) carried out the following actions:
1. She approached Mr. Mason and whispered in his ear that Mr. Rochester was here and wished to see him. 2. She escorted Mr. Mason to the library where Mr. Rochester was waiting. 3. After ensuring Mr. Mason was received by Mr. Rochester, she left the room and went upstairs to her own chamber.
These actions demonstrated Jane's loyalty and willingness to follow Mr. Rochester's wishes in several ways:
1. She did not question Mr. Rochester's instructions or hesitate to carry them out, showing her trust and obedience towards him. 2. She executed the tasks with confidence and determination, moving "straight among" the company and leading Mr. Mason to the library without hesitation. 3. Her loyalty was also revealed through her concern for Mr. Rochester's well-being, as she felt relieved and went to sleep only after hearing his cheerful voice and knowing he was safe and sound.
Overall, Jane's actions demonstrated her strong sense of loyalty, obedience, and care for Mr. Rochester, further solidifying their bond as employer and employee and hinting at her deeper feelings for him.

edge.target: The "beautiful man" that the sisters are referring to is named Mr. Mason. He is a tall, fashionable-looking man from the West Indies, specifically Spanish Town in Jamaica. Mr. Mason's face is sallow because he comes from a hot country, which is why he sits near the hearth and wears a surtout in the house. The narrative suggests that he has just arrived in England after a long journey.

"Now, Dent," continued Mr. Rochester, "it is your turn." And as the other party withdrew, he and his band took the vacated seats. Miss Ingram placed herself at her leader's right hand; the other diviners filled the chairs on each side of him and her. I did not now watch the actors; I no longer waited with interest for the curtain to rise; my attention was absorbed by the spectators; my eyes, erewhile fixed on the arch, were now irresistibly attracted to the semicircle of chairs. What charade Colonel Dent and his party played, what word they chose, how they acquitted themselves, I no longer remember; but I still see the consultation which followed each scene: I see Mr. Rochester turn to Miss Ingram, and Miss Ingram to him; I see her incline her head towards him, till the jetty curls almost touch his shoulder and wave against his cheek; I hear their mutual whisperings; I recall their interchanged glances; and something even of the feeling roused by the spectacle returns in memory at this moment.
I have told you
edge.target:
After the fortune-telling scene with the mysterious woman in the library, Miss Ingram and the others had varying reactions. Miss Ingram returned from the library with a cold and stiff demeanor, not revealing anything about what the fortune-teller had said. She dismissed the experience as an ordinary palm reading and suggested that Mr. Eshton should put the fortune-teller in the stocks the next morning. However, her reaction was likely a cover-up, as she grew momently darker and more dissatisfied, not turning a page of her book for nearly half an hour.
The Misses Eshton and Mary Ingram, on the other hand, were quite shaken by the experience. They claimed that the fortune-teller knew a lot of personal details about them, such as things they had said and done when they were children, books and ornaments in their boudoirs, keepsakes presented by different relations, and even their thoughts and desires. They were so frightened that they ran across the hall, sinking breathlessly into the chairs provided by the gentlemen.
Despite the gentlemen's earnest petitions, Miss Ingram and the others did not reveal the specifics of what the fortune-teller had whispered in their ears regarding the person they liked best in the world and what they most wished for. It can be inferred that the fortune-teller had accurately revealed some intimate details, causing the ladies to be both amazed and frightened.
As for Miss Ingram's private conversation with Mr. Rochester during the charade that followed, the narrator, Jane, did not provide any specific details. However, Jane did mention that she still sees the consultation which followed each scene, with Mr. Rochester turning to Miss Ingram, and Miss Ingram inclining her head towards him, till the jetty curls almost touch his shoulder and wave against his cheek. She also recalls their mutual whisperings and interchanged glances, indicating that there was a strong attraction and connection between the two during that time.

said; they were not seated at table,--the supper was arranged on the sideboard; each had taken what he chose, and they stood about here and there in groups, their plates and glasses in their hands. Every one seemed in high glee; laughter and conversation were general and animated. Mr. Mason stood near the fire, talking to Colonel and Mrs. Dent, and appeared as merry as any of them. I filled a wine-glass (I saw Miss Ingram watch me frowningly as I did so: she thought I was taking a liberty, I daresay), and I returned to the library.
Mr. Rochester's extreme pallor had disappeared, and he looked once more firm and stern. He took the glass from my hand.
"Here is to your health, ministrant spirit!" he said. He swallowed the contents and returned it to me. "What are they doing, Jane?"
"Laughing and talking, sir."
"They don't look grave and mysterious, as if they had heard something strange?"

I have not yet said anything condemnatory of Mr. Rochester's project of marrying for interest and connections. It surprised me when I first discovered that such was his intention: I had thought him a man unlikely to be influenced by motives so commonplace in his choice of a wife; but the longer I considered the position, education, &c., of the parties, the less I felt justified in judging and blaming either him or Miss Ingram for acting in conformity to ideas and principles instilled into them, doubtless, from their childhood. All their class held these principles: I supposed, then, they had reasons for holding them such as I could not fathom. It seemed to me that, were I a gentleman like him, I would take to my bosom only such a wife as I could love; but the very obviousness of the advantages to the husband's own happiness offered by this plan convinced me that

In response to Mr. Rochester's instructions, the narrator (Jane Eyre) carried out the following actions:
1. She approached Mr. Mason and whispered in his ear that Mr. Rochester was here and wished to see him. 2. She escorted Mr. Mason to the library where Mr. Rochester was waiting. 3. After ensuring Mr. Mason was received by Mr. Rochester, she left the room and went upstairs to her own chamber.
These actions demonstrated Jane's loyalty and willingness to follow Mr. Rochester's wishes in several ways:
1. She did not question Mr. Rochester's instructions or hesitate to carry them out, showing her trust and obedience towards him. 2. She executed the tasks with confidence and determination, moving "straight among" the company and leading Mr. Mason to the library without hesitation. 3. Her loyalty was also revealed through her concern for Mr. Rochester's well-being, as she felt relieved and went to sleep only after hearing his cheerful voice and knowing he was safe and sound.
Overall, Jane's actions demonstrated her strong sense of loyalty, obedience, and care for Mr. Rochester, further solidifying their bond as employer and employee and hinting at her deeper feelings for him.

edge.target:
Jane Eyre cannot manage to please Mr. Rochester and become the happiest woman in the world by trying to fit into his project of marrying for interest and connections. The reason is that she doesn't have the social status or wealth that he is looking for in a wife. Moreover, it is clear that Jane and Mr. Rochester are well-suited to each other because of their intellectual equality and mutual respect, which go beyond social standings and financial gains.
To become Mr. Rochester's wife and potentially the happiest woman in the world, Jane needs to be true to herself and follow her heart. She must show Mr. Rochester that she can be a partner to him in every sense, not just a socially acceptable wife. Jane has already shown her loyalty, obedience, and care for Mr. Rochester, which are essential qualities for a successful marriage. However, she must also express her feelings for him and make him see that their love goes beyond social conventions.
In the end, Jane does manage to please Mr. Rochester and become the happiest woman in the world, but not by trying to fit into his original plan of marrying for interest and connections. Instead, she stays true to herself and follows her heart, which leads her to a deeper and more meaningful relationship with Mr. Rochester.

edge.source:
I were in fault.
Some parleying was audible in the hall, and soon the new-comer entered. He bowed to Lady Ingram, as deeming her the eldest lady present.
"It appears I come at an inopportune time, madam," said he, "when my friend, Mr. Rochester, is from home; but I arrive from a very long journey, and I think I may presume so far on old and intimate acquaintance as to instal myself here till he returns."
His manner was polite; his accent, in speaking, struck me as being somewhat unusual,--not precisely foreign, but still not altogether English: his age might be about Mr. Rochester's,--between thirty and forty; his complexion was singularly sallow: otherwise he was a fine-looking man, at first sight especially. On closer examination, you detected something in his face that displeased, or rather that failed to please. His features were regular, but too relaxed: his eye was large and well cut, but the life looking out of it was a tame, vacant life--at least so I thought.
edge.target: The tall, fashionable-looking man who arrived in a post-chaise is named Mason, and he comes from the West Indies, specifically from Spanish Town in Jamaica. When Mr. Rochester left in the morning, he was riding Mesrour, his black horse, and Pilot, his dog was with him. However, when Mason arrived, there was no sign of Mesrour or Pilot, which made Miss Ingram exclaim, "What has he done with the animals?"

"The eagerness of a listener quickens the tongue of a narrator." I said this rather to myself than to the gipsy, whose strange talk, voice, manner, had by this time wrapped me in a kind of dream. In contrast, there is no mention of the stranger receiving similar attention, suggesting that he is less engaging or less well-known to the guests.

The gipsy is described as an old woman with a strange face that looks all brown and black, and she has white hair sticking out from under her hat. She is bent over a little black book, reading it by the firelight and muttering the words to herself. The narrator, who is entering the room for the first time, notices that the gipsy does not immediately look up from her reading when he arrives. Instead, she seems to want to finish what she is reading before acknowledging his presence.
The narrator's initial reaction to the gipsy is one of curiosity and interest, rather than fear or unease. He describes feeling "composed" and notices that there is nothing about the gipsy's appearance that would trouble one's calm. When the gipsy finally looks up at him, he notices that her gaze is bold and direct.
Overall, the gipsy's appearance and behavior suggest that she is a confident and self-assured individual who is deeply engrossed in her reading. The narrator's reaction to her presence reflects his open-mindedness and willingness to engage with new and unexpected experiences.

The speaker's suspicion and speculation during their conversation with Mr. Rochester revolve around his impending marriage to Miss Ingram. The speaker has noticed the frequent and lively conversations between Mr. Rochester and the ladies, as well as his apparent eagerness to listen to their stories. They infer that Mr. Rochester's behavior indicates an interest in matrimony, and when they learn from the gipsy fortune-teller that he is indeed getting married, they conclude it is to Miss Ingram due to the ladies' fascination with him and his receptiveness to their stories.
The speaker justifies their mental state by observing and interpreting the social dynamics and interactions between Mr. Rochester and the ladies at the gathering. The speaker's observations and interpretations of these social cues lead them to form a conclusion about Mr. Rochester's intentions to marry Miss Ingram.

edge.source:
In response to Mr. Rochester's instructions, the narrator (Jane Eyre) carried out the following actions:
1. She approached Mr. Mason and whispered in his ear that Mr. Rochester was here and wished to see him. 2. She escorted Mr. Mason to the library where Mr. Rochester was waiting. 3. After ensuring Mr. Mason was received by Mr. Rochester, she left the room and went upstairs to her own chamber.
These actions demonstrated Jane's loyalty and willingness to follow Mr. Rochester's wishes in several ways:
1. She did not question Mr. Rochester's instructions or hesitate to carry them out, showing her trust and obedience towards him. 2. She executed the tasks with confidence and determination, moving "straight among" the company and leading Mr. Mason to the library without hesitation. 3. Her loyalty was also revealed through her concern for Mr. Rochester's well-being, as she felt relieved and went to sleep only after hearing his cheerful voice and knowing he was safe and sound.
Overall, Jane's actions demonstrated her strong sense of loyalty, obedience, and care for Mr. Rochester, further solidifying their bond as employer and employee and hinting at her deeper feelings for him.
edge.target:
she never offered, nor had, an opinion of her own. She advocated a high tone of sentiment; but she did not know the sensations of sympathy and pity; tenderness and truth were not in her. Too often she betrayed this, by the undue vent she gave to a spiteful antipathy she had conceived against little Adele: pushing her away with some contumelious epithet if she happened to approach her; sometimes ordering her from the room, and always treating her with coldness and acrimony. Other eyes besides mine watched these manifestations of character--watched them closely, keenly, shrewdly. Yes; the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself, exercised over his intended a ceaseless surveillance; and it was from this sagacity--this guardedness of his--this perfect, clear consciousness of his fair one's defects--this obvious absence of passion in his sentiments towards her, that my ever- torturing pain arose.
I saw he was going to marry her, for family, perhaps political reasons, because her rank and connections suited him; I felt he had not given her his love

edge.target:
if I did, I should care nothing about it."
"Then, you could dare censure for my sake?"
"I could dare it for the sake of any friend who deserved my adherence; as you, I am sure, do."
"Go back now into the room; step quietly up to Mason, and whisper in his ear that Mr. Rochester is come and wishes to see him: show him in here and then leave me."
"Yes, sir."
I did his behest. The company all stared at me as I passed straight among them. I sought Mr. Mason, delivered the message, and preceded him from the room: I ushered him into the library, and then I went upstairs.
At a late hour, after I had been in bed some time, I heard the visitors repair to their chambers: I distinguished Mr. Rochester's voice, and heard him say, "This way, Mason; this is your room."
He spoke cheerfully: the gay tones set my heart at ease. I was soon asleep.

edge.target:
admiration--the more truly tranquil my quiescence. But as matters really stood, to watch Miss Ingram's efforts at fascinating Mr. Rochester, to witness their repeated failure--herself unconscious that they did fail; vainly fancying that each shaft launched hit the mark, and infatuatedly pluming herself on success, when her pride and self-complacency repelled further and further what she wished to allure--to witness _this_, was to be at once under ceaseless excitation and ruthless restraint.
Because, when she failed, I saw how she might have succeeded. Arrows that continually glanced off from Mr. Rochester's breast and fell harmless at his feet, might, I knew, if shot by a surer hand, have quivered keen in his proud heart--have called love into his stern eye, and softness into his sardonic face; or, better still, without weapons a silent conquest might have been won.
"Why can she not influence him more, when she is privileged to draw so near to him?" I asked myself. "Surely she cannot truly like him, or not

listener!" repeated she: "yes; Mr. Rochester has sat by the hour, his ear inclined to the fascinating lips that took such delight in their task of communicating; and Mr. Rochester was so willing to receive and looked so grateful for the pastime given him; you have noticed this?"
"Grateful! I cannot remember detecting gratitude in his face."
"Detecting! You have analysed, then. And what did you detect, if not gratitude?"
I said nothing.
"You have seen love: have you not?--and, looking forward, you have seen him married, and beheld his bride happy?"
"Humph! Not exactly. Your witch's skill is rather at fault sometimes."
"What the devil have you seen, then?"
"Never mind: I came here to inquire, not to confess. Is it known that Mr. Rochester is to be married?"
"Yes; and to the beautiful Miss Ingram."
"Shortly?"

interchanged glances; and something even of the feeling roused by the spectacle returns in memory at this moment.
I have told you, reader, that I had learnt to love Mr. Rochester: I could not unlove him now, merely because I found that he had ceased to notice me--because I might pass hours in his presence, and he would never once turn his eyes in my direction--because I saw all his attentions appropriated by a great lady, who scorned to touch me with the hem of her robes as she passed; who, if ever her dark and imperious eye fell on me by chance, would withdraw it instantly as from an object too mean to merit observation. I could not unlove him, because I felt sure he would soon marry this very lady--because I read daily in her a proud security in his intentions respecting her--because I witnessed hourly in him a style of courtship which, if careless and choosing rather to be sought than to seek, was yet, in its very carelessness, captivating, and in its very pride, irresistible.
There was nothing to cool or banish love in these circumstances, though

edge.target:
It is natural to find it difficult to stop loving someone once you have developed feelings for them, even if they are ignoring you or paying attention to someone else. In the narrative provided, Jane Eyre, the protagonist, has learned to love Mr. Rochester, and she cannot stop doing so even when he ignores her and showers his attentions on another woman, Miss Ingram. This is because the feeling of love is not solely based on reciprocation or attention; it is also influenced by the emotional connection, respect, and admiration that Jane has for Mr. Rochester.
Furthermore, Jane's love for Mr. Rochester is not dependent on his careless and prideful courtship of Miss Ingram. Instead, Jane recognizes the superficiality of their relationship and believes that she could have succeeded in winning his heart if she had approached him differently. However, Jane's love for Mr. Rochester is not based on manipulation or strategy; it is grounded in her genuine appreciation for his personality and their intellectual equality.
Therefore, even though Mr. Rochester is ignoring Jane and paying attention to someone else, she cannot stop loving him because her feelings are based on a deeper connection that goes beyond social conventions and external displays of affection.

Because, when she failed, I saw how she might have succeeded. Arrows that continually glanced off from Mr. Rochester's breast and fell harmless at his feet, might, I knew, if shot by a surer hand, have quivered keen in his proud heart--have called love into his stern eye, and softness into his sardonic face; or, better still, without weapons a silent conquest might have been won.

Therefore, even though Mr. Rochester is ignoring Jane and paying attention to someone else, she cannot stop loving him because her feelings are based on a deeper connection that goes beyond social conventions and external displays of affection.

I have told you, reader, that I had learnt to love Mr. Rochester: I could not unlove him now, merely because I found that he had ceased to notice me--because I might pass hours in his presence, and he would never once turn his eyes in my direction--because I saw all his attentions appropriated by a great lady, who scorned to touch me with the hem of her robes as she passed; who, if ever her dark and imperious eye fell on me by chance, would withdraw it instantly as from an object too mean to merit observation. I could not unlove him, because I felt sure he would soon marry this very lady--because I read daily in her a proud security in his intentions respecting her--because I witnessed hourly in him a style of courtship which, if careless and choosing rather to be sought than to seek, was yet, in its very carelessness, captivating, and in its very pride, irresistible.
There was nothing to cool or banish love in these circumstances, though

smile signify?"
"Wonder and self-congratulation, sir. I have your permission to retire now, I suppose?"
"No; stay a moment; and tell me what the people in the drawing-room yonder are doing."
"Discussing the gipsy, I daresay."
"Sit down!--Let me hear what they said about me."
"I had better not stay long, sir; it must be near eleven o'clock. Oh, are you aware, Mr. Rochester, that a stranger has arrived here since you left this morning?"
"A stranger!--no; who can it be? I expected no one; is he gone?"
"No; he said he had known you long, and that he could take the liberty of installing himself here till you returned."
"The devil he did! Did he give his name?"
"His name is Mason, sir; and he comes from the West Indies; from Spanish Town, in Jamaica, I think."
Mr. Rochester was standing near me; he had taken my hand, as if to lead me to a chair.

"What can possess him to come home in that style?" said Miss Ingram. "He rode Mesrour (the black horse), did he not, when he went out? and Pilot was with him:--what has he done with the animals?"
As she said this, she approached her tall person and ample garments so near the window, that I was obliged to bend back almost to the breaking of my spine: in her eagerness she did not observe me at first, but when she did, she curled her lip and moved to another casement. The post-chaise stopped; the driver rang the door-bell, and a gentleman alighted attired in travelling garb; but it was not Mr. Rochester; it was a tall, fashionable-looking man, a stranger.
"How provoking!" exclaimed Miss Ingram: "you tiresome monkey!" (apostrophising Adele), "who perched you up in the window to give false intelligence?" and she cast on me an angry glance, as if I were in fault.
Some parleying was audible in the hall, and soon the new-comer entered. He bowed to Lady Ingram

"You don't know the gentlemen here? You have not exchanged a syllable with one of them? Will you say that of the master of the house!"
"He is not at home."
"A profound remark! A most ingenious quibble! He went to Millcote this morning, and will be back here to-night or to-morrow: does that circumstance exclude him from the list of your acquaintance--blot him, as it were, out of existence?"

"Do you know," said she, "that, of the three characters, I liked you in the last best? Oh, had you but lived a few years earlier, what a gallant gentleman-highwayman you would have made!"
"Is all the soot washed from my face?" he asked, turning it towards her.
"Alas! yes: the more's the pity! Nothing could be more becoming to your complexion than that ruffian's rouge."
"You would like a hero of the road then?"
"An English hero of the road would be the next best thing to an Italian bandit; and that could only be surpassed by a Levantine pirate."
"Well, whatever I am, remember you are my wife; we were married an hour since, in the presence of all these witnesses." She giggled, and her colour rose.
